title: Top 5 Anime to Watch This Summer
excerpt: Looking for something new and exciting to watch? These five anime are making waves this season.
content:
Summer 2025 is stacked with anime that promise to bring the heat — emotionally, visually, and plot-wise. Whether you’re into epic action, chill slice-of-life, or trippy fantasy, this season has something for you. Here are the top five anime you absolutely shouldn’t miss.

1. Celestial Pulse

A breathtaking sci-fi adventure set in a spacefaring future where music powers starships. Think Macross meets Vivy. With a killer soundtrack and animation that rivals UFOtable, Celestial Pulse is already being called the surprise hit of the season.

2. My Shogun Can't Be This Cute

A historical rom-com with a twist: a modern-day girl wakes up in feudal Japan — and is mistaken for the Shogun! Packed with humor, sword fights, and heartwarming moments, this one’s for fans of Kaguya-sama and Inuyasha.

3. Under the Ice Moon

Studio Yoru returns with a moody supernatural mystery set in a town where the moon hasn’t moved in 100 years. Gorgeous backgrounds, tense pacing, and a layered story about grief and time make this a must-watch.

4. Battle Baking: Reheat the World

Yes, it’s a battle anime about bread. Yes, it’s amazing. Combining Food Wars energy with Dragon Ball Z absurdity, this anime follows a young baker trying to revive the soul of the culinary world — one punch-crust pastry at a time.

5. YumeLink Online

VRMMO anime are back, and this one stands out. Players in YumeLink discover that their dreams affect the game world. Action, romance, and dream logic twists make it this summer’s best binge candidate.

Honorable Mentions: Sunset Synthwave, Classroom of Shadows, and the second season of Witch’s Dorm Diaries.

Which of these are on your watchlist? Drop your picks in the comments!

title: Why Elden Ring Still Dominates RPG Gaming
excerpt: Even years after release, Elden Ring continues to set the standard for open-world RPGs. Here's why it refuses to be dethroned.
content:
Elden Ring launched in 2022 and immediately changed the landscape of RPG gaming. It wasn’t just a hit — it was a seismic event. Now, years later, while other titles have come and gone, Elden Ring remains a benchmark that players and developers still compare everything to. So why does it still hold the throne?

1. The World is a Masterclass in Discovery

Limgrave alone felt bigger and richer than most full games. Every cliff, ruin, and dungeon feels handcrafted — begging to be explored. No map markers. No forced paths. Just curiosity.

2. The Lore is Deep (and Optional)

Thanks to the genius of George R.R. Martin and FromSoftware’s cryptic storytelling, the lore feels like a rabbit hole. You don’t need to read every item description, but if you do — prepare for a dark, tragic, and beautifully interconnected world.

3. Combat is Brutal but Fair

It rewards patience, skill, and strategy. Magic builds, dual greatswords, poison daggers — everything feels viable if you learn it. And bosses? Unforgettable. Radahn. Malenia. Placidusax. Legends.

4. Freedom of Playstyle

Want to sneak around with a dagger and no armor? Summon spectral wolves and fight on horseback? Go full Gandalf and throw comets from the sky? You can. The build variety is staggering and fun to experiment with.

5. It Respects the Player

No handholding. No microtransactions. No minimap spam. It trusts you to find your own way — and in doing so, makes the victories feel earned. That’s rare in modern gaming.

6. The Community Keeps It Alive

Between challenge runs, lore videos, PvP tournaments, and co-op play, the community is constantly breathing life into the game. Mods and randomizers continue to add new ways to play.

In a world of live-service fluff and over-monetized titles, Elden Ring stands tall as a complete experience — a love letter to exploration, challenge, and immersion. And with DLC content and spiritual successors still rumored or in development, its reign might not end anytime soon.

What’s your favorite moment in Elden Ring? Did you beat Malenia solo? Let’s hear your stories below.

title: The Evolution of Anime Art Styles
excerpt: From hand-drawn classics to digital stylization, anime's visual language has transformed over the decades. Let’s explore how and why.
content:
Anime is more than just storytelling — it's an art form with a rich visual identity. And like any art form, it evolves with time. From the thick-outlined heroes of the '70s to the hyper-polished characters of today, anime’s art styles reflect both cultural shifts and technological advances. Here’s how it’s changed — and why it matters.

1. The Retro Era (1960s–1980s)

This era gave us big eyes, minimal shading, and unforgettable silhouettes. Artists like Osamu Tezuka (the ‘God of Manga’) helped define this look. Think Astro Boy, Speed Racer, and early Gundam. Limited animation techniques forced creators to get creative with movement and camera tricks — and it worked.

2. The OVA Boom (Late '80s–1990s)

Original Video Animations (OVAs) exploded in this period, pushing production values higher. More detail, edgier character designs, experimental shading. Akira and Ghost in the Shell still look stunning today. Hair got wilder, eyes more expressive, and worlds darker and more cyberpunk.

3. The Digital Transition (2000s)

Studios moved from hand-painted cels to digital coloring. This made production faster but changed the aesthetic. Colors became cleaner, gradients smoother. Some fans missed the texture of analog, but series like Fullmetal Alchemist and Death Note proved digital could be dynamic and cinematic.

4. The Moe Era (Late 2000s–2010s)

As slice-of-life and school genres boomed, so did the ‘moe’ style — soft lines, blushing cheeks, sparkly eyes. Shows like K-On!, Clannad, and Lucky Star led the charge. Some celebrated the cuteness, others criticized the homogeneity.

5. The Modern Renaissance (2020s)

Today, we’re seeing bold blends: 3D and 2D hybrids (Beastars), hyper-fluid sakuga scenes (Demon Slayer), stylized throwbacks (Ranking of Kings), and experimental visuals (Ping Pong, Keep Your Hands Off Eizouken!). Technology allows anything — but style now becomes a choice, not a limitation.

6. What’s Next?

AI-assisted animation? More indie studios rising? International collaborations? The future of anime art is wide open — and that's what makes it so exciting.

One thing is certain: anime’s art will keep evolving, just like the stories it tells. Whether you love the retro grit or the polished gloss, there's something to admire in every era.

Which art style era do you love most? Let us know below — and drop your favorite “best-looking” anime picks!

title: Beginner’s Guide to Building a Custom PC in 2025
excerpt: Building your own PC in 2025 is easier than ever — and way more customizable. Here’s everything you need to get started.
content:
There’s something incredibly satisfying about powering on a PC you built with your own two hands. Whether you’re gaming, creating content, or just want more control over your hardware, building a PC gives you better performance and value. And in 2025, with improved part compatibility and beginner-friendly tools, there’s never been a better time to start.

1. What You’ll Need

  • CPU (Processor) – The brain of your build. Choose AMD Ryzen 7000 or Intel 14th Gen for top performance.
  • GPU (Graphics Card) – Crucial for gaming and rendering. NVIDIA RTX 4000 series and AMD RX 7000 series dominate right now.
  • Motherboard – Make sure it matches your CPU socket (e.g., AM5 or LGA1700).
  • RAM (Memory) – 16GB is the starting point. 32GB is ideal for gaming + multitasking.
  • Storage – Go NVMe SSD. 1TB minimum. They’re fast and affordable now.
  • Power Supply (PSU) – 650W–850W is safe for most builds. Look for 80+ Bronze or better.
  • Case – ATX, mATX, or Mini-ITX depending on your style and parts.
  • Cooling – Stock coolers are fine, but AIO or air coolers can lower temps and noise.

2. Tools & Prep

You’ll need a Phillips screwdriver, a static-free workspace, and some patience. Optional but handy: zip ties for cable management, thermal paste (some coolers include it), and a magnetic parts tray.

3. Step-by-Step Build Flow

  1. Install CPU, RAM, and cooler on the motherboard
  2. Mount the motherboard in the case
  3. Install the PSU
  4. Connect case fans and front-panel headers
  5. Install GPU and storage
  6. Double-check connections and manage cables
  7. Boot up and enter BIOS to confirm system detects everything
  8. Install Windows or Linux + drivers

4. Mistakes to Avoid

  • Forgetting to remove plastic from the CPU cooler
  • Plugging in the 4+4 CPU power cable in the wrong spot
  • Skipping BIOS updates if needed
  • Cheap power supplies — don’t risk it!

5. 2025-Specific Tips

  • DDR5 RAM is now mainstream — check your motherboard supports it
  • New GPUs support frame generation and AI upscaling — make sure your monitor can keep up
  • Windows 11 is optimized for newer CPUs — TPM 2.0 support is a must

Building a PC is one of the best ways to learn how your machine works — and unlock serious performance on a budget.

Have you built your own PC yet? Share your build or ask questions below!

title: Hidden Gem: Made in Abyss
excerpt: Don’t let the cute art style fool you — Made in Abyss is one of the darkest, most emotionally devastating anime you’ll ever see.
content:
At first glance, Made in Abyss looks like a whimsical fantasy adventure. Chibi characters, lush environments, and a dreamy orchestral soundtrack. But beneath its charming surface lies a story that is brutally honest, emotionally raw, and unlike anything else in modern anime.

1. A World That Feels Alive — and Hungry

The Abyss is a giant, mysterious pit that stretches far into the Earth, filled with ancient relics and deadly creatures. Each layer feels like a different ecosystem — with its own rules, monsters, and dangers. The deeper you go, the less human it gets. And once you descend… you might not come back.

2. Beautiful Meets Horrific

The animation is stunning — watercolor backgrounds, soft lighting, and expressive character designs. But the contrast is shocking: the show’s darkest moments are gut-wrenching. It’s one of the few anime that can make you cry and cringe in the same episode.

3. Emotional Weight That Sticks

Riko and Reg’s journey isn’t just a physical descent — it’s emotional. They face death, grief, sacrifice, and moral dilemmas that feel painfully real. Characters grow, break, and change. And yes — Nanachi’s backstory will wreck you.

4. Music That Elevates the Story

Kevin Penkin’s score is an absolute masterpiece. Haunting, hopeful, alien. The music makes every moment — whether it’s awe, despair, or tension — hit ten times harder. It’s one of the best anime soundtracks in years.

5. For Mature Audiences

This is NOT a kid’s show. It tackles body horror, trauma, and intense psychological themes. Viewer discretion is very much advised — but for those who can handle it, it’s unforgettable.

Made in Abyss isn’t just a hidden gem — it’s a rare diamond. Brutally honest, heartbreakingly beautiful, and courageously unique. If you’re tired of predictable anime and want something that challenges you, this is it.

Have you made the descent into the Abyss? Let us know your thoughts, and which scenes hit you the hardest.
